items.name: String Instruments
items.description: Instruments that produce sound through vibrating strings.
items.details: String instruments create sound when strings are plucked, struck, or bowed. They are found in nearly every musical tradition and are essential in classical, folk, and popular music.
examples: Ranges from high violin to low double bass

items.name: Piano
items.description: A keyboard instrument with 88 keys spanning 7+ octaves.
items.details: The piano is a percussion instrument with strings struck by hammers. Used across all genres - classical, jazz, pop, and more. Excellent for learning music theory.

items.name: Guitar (Acoustic/Electric)
items.description: A string instrument with typically 6 strings and 20+ frets.
items.details: Acoustic and electric variants. Extremely versatile - used in blues, rock, jazz, folk, classical. Great for chord work and melody.
examples: Rock: Jimi Hendrix, Eddie Van Halen

items.name: Violin
items.description: A bowed string instrument with 4 strings, highest in the violin family.
items.details: One of the highest-pitched orchestral instruments. Essential in classical, baroque, and folk music. Also used in jazz and contemporary music.

items.name: Cello
items.description: A large bowed string instrument with 4 strings, lower pitched than violin.
items.details: One of the most expressive orchestral instruments. Used in classical music, film scores, and contemporary genres. Sits between violin and bass in pitch range.

items.name: Viola
items.description: A bowed string instrument slightly larger than violin with deeper tone.
items.details: The middle voice in the string family. Essential in chamber music and orchestras. Richer, warmer tone than violin.

items.name: Double Bass (Upright Bass)
items.description: The largest and lowest-pitched string instrument, played with a bow or plucked.
items.details: Essential in orchestras and jazz ensembles. Also called upright bass or contrabass. Provides the foundation of the harmonic structure.

items.name: Harp
items.description: A string instrument played by plucking, used across many cultures.
items.details: Ancient instrument known for ethereal, shimmering tones. Essential in orchestral music and folk traditions. Complex technique but beautiful sound.

items.name: Mandolin
items.description: A small string instrument with paired strings, common in folk and bluegrass music.
items.details: Bright, percussive tone. Essential in bluegrass, classical, and world music. Two strings per note provide a shimmering effect.

items.name: Ukulele
items.description: A small string instrument originating from Hawaii, easy to learn and portable.
items.details: Cheerful, warm tone. Comes in soprano, concert, tenor, and baritone sizes. Perfect for beginners and folk music. Versatile across many genres.

items.name: Bass Guitar (Electric/Acoustic)
items.description: A string instrument with typically 4 strings, lower register than guitar.
items.details: Provides the bridge between harmony and rhythm in most modern music. Electric bass is standard in rock, pop, funk, and jazz.
examples: Rock: John Entwistle, John Paul Jones

items.name: Brass Instruments
items.description: Instruments made of brass that produce sound through vibrating air columns.
items.details: Brass instruments are played by blowing air into a mouthpiece. They require strong breath control and embouchure. Essential in orchestras, jazz, and brass bands.
examples: From bright trumpet to deep tuba
Core of jazz and orchestral brass sections

items.name: Trumpet
items.description: A brass instrument with 3 valves, known for bright, cutting tone.
items.details: Essential in jazz, orchestral, and brass band music. Requires strong breath control and embouchure. Can play loud, cutting notes or soft, mellow ones.

items.name: French Horn
items.description: A brass instrument with a conical bore and valves, known for mellow, warm tone.
items.details: Versatile brass instrument used in orchestras, chamber music, and occasionally jazz. Requires precise embouchure. Can sound both delicate and powerful.

items.name: Trombone
items.description: A brass instrument with a sliding tube instead of valves, known for expressive glissandos.
items.details: Essential in jazz and orchestras. The slide mechanism allows for glissandos and expressive bends. Can play smooth or sharp articulations.

items.name: Tuba
items.description: The largest and lowest-pitched brass instrument with a deep, powerful sound.
items.details: Essential for providing bass lines in orchestras and brass bands. Requires strong breath control. Can play both rhythmic and melodic roles.
examples: Folk: Polka and brass band traditions

items.name: Woodwind Instruments
items.description: Wind instruments traditionally made of wood that produce sound through vibrating reeds or air columns.
items.details: Woodwind instruments require breath control and fingering technique. Despite the name, some modern woodwinds are made of metal. Essential in orchestras and bands.
examples: From high flute to deep bassoon
Core of orchestral and wind band sections

items.name: Saxophone
items.description: A woodwind instrument with a single reed and brass body, available in multiple sizes.
items.details: Invented in the 19th century, essential in jazz. Comes in soprano, alto, tenor, and baritone varieties. Rich, warm tone that blends well in ensembles.

items.name: Clarinet
items.description: A woodwind instrument with a single reed and cylindrical body.
items.details: Versatile instrument spanning multiple octaves. Essential in classical orchestras, jazz, and folk music. Can play both bright and mellow tones.

items.name: Flute
items.description: A woodwind instrument with no reed, played by blowing across an embouchure hole.
items.details: One of the oldest instruments. Light, airy tone. Used in orchestras, folk music, and contemporary genres. Piccolo is the smaller, higher-pitched variant.

items.name: Oboe
items.description: A woodwind instrument with a double reed producing a bright, penetrating sound.
items.details: Expressive and agile. Often plays the highest melodic lines in orchestras. Can sound nasal and intense or warm and mellow.

items.name: Percussion Instruments
items.description: Instruments that produce sound through striking, shaking, or scraping.
items.details: Percussion instruments are the primary timekeepers in music. Includes both pitched (drums, timpani) and unpitched (cymbals, triangles) instruments.
examples: From melodic timpani to rhythmic hi-hats

items.name: Drums (Drum Kit)
items.description: A collection of percussion instruments including kick, snare, toms, hi-hat, and cymbals.
items.details: The foundation of rhythm in rock, pop, jazz, and modern music. Requires coordination between all four limbs. Essential for timekeeping.

items.name: Keyboard Instruments
items.description: Instruments played using a keyboard of keys, found across many sound-generation methods.
items.details: Keyboard instruments range from acoustic pianos with mechanical actions to electronic synthesizers with endless sound possibilities.
examples: From acoustic piano to digital synthesizer
Used in every musical genre and style

items.name: Organ
items.description: A keyboard instrument with pipes or electronic amplification producing various tones.
items.details: Comes in pipe organ (church/concert halls) and electronic organ (portable) variants. Produces extremely rich, full sounds. Essential in classical and gospel music.

items.name: Synthesizer
items.description: An electronic instrument that generates and modifies sound using oscillators and filters.
items.details: Produces unlimited sounds - from imitations of acoustic instruments to completely new tones. Essential in electronic music, pop, and contemporary genres.

items.name: Voice / Vocals
items.description: The human voice as a musical instrument, the most universal and expressive instrument.
items.details: The human voice is capable of great expression and emotion. Ranges from bass to soprano depending on individual physiology and training.
examples: Used in every musical genre and culture
Most direct expression of emotion in music

items.name: Vocals (Human Voice)
items.description: The human voice as a musical instrument, capable of great expression and emotion.
items.details: Ranges from bass to soprano depending on individual. Used in every genre. The voice carries emotion and lyrics. Can be trained extensively.
